snippet.title: Beer brew fundraiser to help save Tasmania's endangered giant freshwater lobsters
snippet.content:
Conservationists say the first case of a crowdfunded beer designed to help save Tasmania's giant freshwater lobster will be sent to Federal Environment Minister Josh Frydenberg. Mr Frydenberg will receive The species is only found in Tasmania's north, and is listed as vulnerable under federal and state law. A review of the recovery plan was undertaken in 2015, and it was released for public consultation in August last year. The Wilderness Society's Tasmanian campaign manager Vica Bayley said he could not understand the hold up. "The lobster is at risk from logging, land clearing and other activities such as poaching," he said. "We know that it's a good recovery plan that makes some strong recommendations about habitat protection. "We need Minister Frydenberg to sign that plan, and then we need for him to step in and make sure the Tasmanian Government does its job, declares new reserves over key areas of lobster habitat, and gives this species the best chance of survival."

Giant freshwater lobster researcher Todd Walsh wants "urgent action" to protect the species. The Wilderness Society said it was concerned about the Tasmanian Government's push to allow logging in 356,000 hectares of forests that were currently off limits. The contentious legislation was defeated in the Upper House in June "This is forest that is key habitat for the freshwater lobster, there has long been recommendations for this habitat to be formally and securely protected in national parks and reserves," Mr Bayley said.
The Wilderness Society has turned to crowdfunding to raise $20,000 for a Tasmanian brewer to create the beer, with the profits going into a program to protect the species. "We will be sending the first case to Minister Josh Frydenberg himself," Mr Bayley said. Giant freshwater lobster researcher Todd Walsh said urgent action was needed to protect the species. "The wheels of government are turning really slowly for this animal," he said. "If the plan got signed off and protocols were followed and recommendations were followed, you'd probably find this animal is going to be looked after pretty well."
